turn.0: Hi, I'm your automated assistant. I can answer your questions about The Old Tune.
turn.1: What did critics say about The Old Tune?
turn.2: In 1934, Beckett, in a review of O’Casey's "Windfalls", which includes two one-act plays, writes:  Gorman and Cream's worlds are crumbling around them just as their pasts and memories are doing.
turn.3: What are some other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.4: Their speech is colloquial, their outlook parochial.
turn.5: What did the public think of the play?
turn.6: The modern world is passing them by – literally – motor vehicles and the young on the street.
turn.7: What were some of the more notable critics?
turn.8: Despite Beckett's conscious efforts to Gaelicise the work the themes at its core are universal.
turn.9: Are there any other interesting aspects about this article?
turn.10: Gorman's line, “You had to work for your living in those days, it wasn’t at six you knocked off, nor at seven neither, eight it was, eight o’clock, yes by God,” could be slipped almost unnoticed into the "Four Yorkshiremen sketch" – made famous by Monty Python – or just as easily Neil Simon’s "The Sunshine Boys".
turn.11: What made the play even more memorable?
turn.12: There is a clear contrast between O’Casey’s linguistic pyrotechnics and the limited, impoverished lives of the characters that utter his rich hyperbole; the result is both comic and tragic but it is clear that Beckett is in his debt.
